awd_titl_txt: Conflict and Coevolution in a Plastid- Nuclear Enzyme Complex
awd_abstract_narration:
Although genes within living organisms generally interact in mutually beneficial ways, opportunities also exist for "selfish" conflict between genes, when some genes direct their own survival, possibly to the exclusion of other genes. This project will investigate the possibility that such "warfare" between genes in the nuclear DNA and genes in the separate plastid (chloroplast) DNA is responsible for very fast evolutionary changes in protein sequences that have been observed in many groups of flowering plants. The research activities will provide training opportunities for student and postdoctoral researchers in advanced techniques in biotechnology and computational genomics. This research and training will be integrated with educational workshops that will expose early-stage undergraduates to career opportunities in the field of bioinformatics. Students will also help organize workshops in Mexico; these international service-learning experiences will be designed with the goal of boosting recruitment and retention at the US universities of underrepresented minority groups in technical and quantitative disciplines.

The research project will focus on a protease enzyme complex (Clp) in plastids that exhibits accelerated evolution and extreme signatures of positive selection in both plastid- and nuclear-encoded subunits. Biochemical and phenotypic consequences of changes in protein sequences will be investigated by modifying the plastid genome in the Nicotiana tabacum model system. Proteomic techniques will be used to assess assembly of the enzyme complex and effects of the protease on plastid protein content. Finally, comparative genomic approaches will be used to analyze correlated rates of protein sequence evolution to discover previously unrecognized interactions between plastid and nuclear genes. Collectively, these lines of investigation will test the hypothesis that antagonistic plastid-nuclear interactions have driven accelerated evolution of the plastid Clp complex.

por.por_cntn:
Many enzymes are assembled from multiple protein subunits. In plant chloroplasts, these subunits can be encoded by genes in two different genomes because chloroplasts contain their own genomes but also import thousands of proteins that are encoded by nuclear genes. When proteins interact in this intimate fashion, it creates an opportunity for changes in one subunit to create selection for coevolutionary responses in another. This project used the chloroplast caseinolytic protease (Clp) enzyme complex as a model to understand coevolutionary relationships between nuclear- and chloroplast-encoded protein subunits. This complex, which functions to regulate protein degradation and quality control in chloroplasts, is a valuable study system because it has undergone extreme increases in rates of protein sequence change in multiple groups of flowering plants. This award used proteomic approaches to confirm that the Clp complex still is still expressed and assembled even in species with extreme sequence divergence. To test the functional effects of this history of sequence divergence, mismatches between subunits from different species were generated by genetically modified chloroplast genomes to replace the native copies of a key Clp gene. This work showed that species with rapid rates of Clp protein sequence evolution build up genetic incompatibilities with other species faster than close relatives with slow rates of sequence evolution. Although this relationship between evolutionary rate and the emergence of genetic incompatibilities has been widely assumed in previous work on chloroplast-nuclear coevolution, this study represents some of the first experimental support. Finally, the project employed computational methods to scan entire plant genomes to identify genes that might be functionally related to subunits in the Clp complex based on the principle that functional interactions can lead to correlated changes in rates of sequence evolution between two proteins across branches in the tree of life. The analysis was used to investigate proteins with previously undescribed interactions with the Clp complex. It also revealed evidence that numerous groups of flowering have experienced extensive perturbations to the genetic machinery required for chloroplast protein synthesis, import and turnover. These perturbations might be important for understanding variation in chloroplast function across plant diversity, but the specific causes of these perturbations is yet to be determined.

 

The research activities provided technical training in key computational and biotechnological disciplines for 18 researchers, ranging from undergraduates to senior research scientists. The project also supported education and outreach efforts, including international service learning workshops on computational biology and a program to introduce first-year undergraduates at Colorado State University to career and training opportunities in computational biology.
